Award.AwardTitle: New Approaches for Stereoselective Formation of Quaternary Carbon Stereocenters and Fragment Coupling
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Overman. Professor Overman is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at the University of California, Irvine. He proposes to develop new ways to join complex molecular fragments to prepare high-value organic molecules. By building complex pieces of a molecule independently and then coupling them together at the end of a synthesis, inefficient linear sequences that build the entire structure one step at a time can be avoided. The method under development is particularly impressive in that it combines the complex fragments in a one to one ratio. Thus, it avoids the more common need to waste valuable material by using one of the complex fragments in excess. In these studies, Professor Overman and his coworkers employ photoredox catalysis for the coupling reactions. Such transformation are attractive because they use visible light as the energy source for making new bonds. This use of sustainable energy for the reactions help to minimize their environmental impact. The broad scope of the research involving photocatalysis, mechanistic and target-directed synthesis objectives is well suited for the education of scientists at all levels. Professor Overman's group has a long established record of providing the highest level of education and training for coworkers including those underrepresented in science. Many of these students now hold leading positions in both academics and the pharmaceutical industry.

Bimolecular chemical reactions that combine complex fragments in good yield, and, where important, with high stereocontrol, are fundamental for implementing convergent synthetic strategies. When the atoms joined in a fragment-coupling step are chiral, this union is particularly challenging. Recent discoveries from Professor Overman's laboratories show that bimolecular reactions of structurally elaborate tertiary carbon radicals and electron-deficient alkenes can join complex fragments by forming new bonds in high yields and high stereocontrol using equimolar (or nearly equimolar) amounts of the two coupling partners. Such chemical transformations are not currently a common part of the repertoire of organic synthesis, yet hold exciting potential to solve formidable challenges in constructing complex organic molecules. The proposed studies define the mechanism and optimize the generation and coupling of tertiary radicals formed from tertiary alcohol hemioxalate precursors, explore 1,6-additions of carbon radicals to electrophilic dienes and develop multicomponent radical-anionic crossover reactions, and define the utility of tertiary-radical fragment coupling strategies in the enantioselective total synthesis of structurally elaborate diterpenoids harboring dioxobicyclo[3.3.0]octanone fragments and ent-kaurene diterpenoids. These organic reactions have important technical broader impacts on the pharmaceutical industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Organic chemical compounds permeate our daily lives. They play an essential role in such diverse fields as genetics, materials science, nutrition, medicine, energy, transportation, homeland security, and consumer products. Each of these fields depends in one way or another on our ability to make organic molecules, the knowledge of which rests on an understanding of the fundamentals of chemical structure and reactivity and chemical synthesis strategy. High-value organic chemicals?such as those in prescription pharmaceutical agents?are composed of hundreds to thousands of atoms, in most cases organized on a backbone of the atom carbon. Their synthesis involves piecing together the complex carbon framework and additional atom functionality to dictate the molecule?s three-dimensional structure and thus function. There are two distinct ways to build such molecules: a linear fashion in which each successive step adds to the molecule?s complexity, or in a convergent fashion in which individual fragments of some complexity are assembled and then combined. The linear strategy is rarely preferred, as the overall yield of the target molecule is eroded by the efficiency of each successive step. A convergent strategy avoids this disadvantage. As a result, reactions that can combine complex fragments in good yield, and, where important, with high three-dimensional control of structure, are essential for implementing convergent synthetic strategies.

The objective of the research undertaken with support of this NSF grant was to develop new convergent synthesis strategies employing visible light and a photocatalyst that unite a tertiary carbon radical with an alkene or heteroarene to form new highly congested (i.e., difficult to fashion) carbon-carbon bonds. As verified in various exploratory investigations and in targeted chemical synthesis of structurally complex molecules of natural origin (diterpenoids), this type of chemical reaction holds enormous promise for uniting complex fragments during the convergent synthesis of valuable, structurally elaborate organic molecules. Moreover, the use of visible light instead of heat to promote chemical reactivity has notable environmental advantages. It was demonstrated for the first time that the coupling of tertiary carbon radicals with pi-bonds can be carried out using equimolar amounts of the two addends, thus avoiding the production of chemical waste and allowing this transformation to be used in the late-stage union of structurally complex molecular fragments in efficient convergent synthesis strategies.

We anticipate that the chemical synthesis methods developed in this research will be of most use in biomedical research and in the discovery and potentially production of high-value organic molecules such as pharmaceuticals. In addition, this project resulted in the training of Ph.D. students and postdoctoral fellows who subsequently moved on to research positions in the U.S. pharmaceutical industry or assistant professorships at U.S. research universities.
